newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil oilworkers unhappy with Petrobras pay offer.
newsitem.headline: Brazil oilworkers unhappy with Petrobras pay offer.

text.p: Brazil's oil workers and state-owned oil company Petrobras are sharply divided over proposed pay increases in their annual salary talks, a spokeswoman for the oil union federation said.

The United Oilworkers' Federation (FUP), which represents the country's 20 oil workers' unions, is asking for a total pay rise of 46.64 percent, compared with Petrobras' offer of 8.8 percent, said FUP spokeswoman Leila Costa. The federation is also asking for contract guarantees of job security, preventing arbitrary or collective dismissals.
"Petrobras' pay offer is unacceptable," Costa said. "We won't be inflexible, but we're waiting to see whether the company will increase its offer."
FUP's pay hike figure is based on September 1995 to August 1996 inflation, unpaid inflation adjustments for July and August 1995, and annual productivity gains.
Costa said it was too early to speak of any strike action.
"The possibility always exists, but it's still too early to say," she said. "We have to wait and see what further talks with the company will bring. So far we are not considering any strike action."
Costa said FUP and Petrobras officials were due to meet again next week.
Petrobras had not explained why it offered only 8.8 percent, but the government was pressing for low public sector pay rises to keep inflation in check, Costa added.
-- Simona de Logu, Rio de Janeiro newsroom, 5521 507 4151
